properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow will occur beginning this afternoon. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to give blowing snow with widespread visibilities reduced to 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VERNON (March 3, 2021 - Vernon) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Vernon because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is a concern for pregnant women, infants, and older adults, as well as, individuals with conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, diabetes or respiratory infections such as COVID-19. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath,cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-04T23:00:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-04T07:01:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2165722089.2021

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 centimetres are expected by Friday. The snow will fall rapidly today and will ease in the evening. Additionally, today, southerly winds reaching up to 70 kilometres per hour will combine with the snow to generate blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-05T02:09:42-00:00

Area: Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Maximum wind gusts: north to northwesterly near 60 km/h. Further snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Time span: this afternoon. Remarks: Persistent light to moderate snow, strong northerly winds, and cold temperatures will combine to give frequent extended periods of reduced visibilities in blowing and drifting snow. Conditions are expected to improve this afternoon as the snow tapers off and the winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-04T19:59:04-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An Arctic air mass is producing extremely cold weather conditions. Wind chill values near minus 38 are expected this morning. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring over some areas. The combination of clear skies, light winds and melting snow created ideal conditions for fog development overnight. As a result, widespread reduced visibilities are being reported over a number of locations in the southern prairies this morning. The fog is expected to dissipated toward midday but will likely develop over the region tonight into Friday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: generally 5 to 10 cm, with locally 15 cm or more possible in areas of heavier snow. Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly 70 km/h. Locations: western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: tonight through Thursday. Remarks: Periods of snow and possible snow squalls will combine with strong southwesterly winds to cause poor visibility in blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: generally 5 to 10 cm, with locally near 15 cm in areas of heavier snow. Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly 70 km/h. Locations: western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: today Remarks: Periods of snow will begin to taper to flurries and snow squalls this afternoon. Strong winds will continue to cause frequent periods of near zero visibility in blowing snow today. Conditions will generally improve later this afternoon, but poor visibility will likely remain under snow squalls tonight. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of extremely cold wind chill values, as low as minus 65, continues this morning. After moderating somewhat this afternoon, wind chill values near minus 55 will develop again tonight. Temperatures will rise by Saturday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A frontal system will approach Vancouver Island today bringing strong winds to West Vancouver Island. Southeast winds of 80 gusting to 100 km/h will develop this morning and then ease and become southwesterly late this afternoon. A second system will approach the west coast of Vancouver Island early on Friday morning with winds once again increasing to southeast 80 gusting to 100 km/h. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-05T04:58:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-04T12:59:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1883191122.2021
Area: West Vancouver Island

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An approaching low pressure system west of Vancouver Island this morning will track northwards to lie over Haida Gwaii this evening. Ahead of the low, southeast winds of 90 km/h gusting to 110 will develop this afternoon over North Vancouver Island, Central Coast Coastal Sections and Haida Gwaii, then spread to North Coast Coastal section in the evening. Winds will ease later this evening as the low moves north into the Alaskan Panhandle. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-05T05:03:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-04T13:04:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2348366142.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii, North Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An approaching low pressure system west of Vancouver Island on Thursday will track northwards to lie over Haida Gwaii in the afternoon. Ahead of the low, southeast winds of 90 km/h will develop midday Thursday over Haida Gwaii and North Vancouver Island, then spread to the central coast in the afternoon. Winds will ease Thursday evening as the low moves north into the Alaskan Panhandle. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-04T15:33:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-03T23:34:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2083726073.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii, North Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections
